 23: ctypedef np.float64_t DTYPE_t


 24: 


 25: "A parameter for optimizing calculations of adaptive moments by\n"


 26: "cutting off profiles. This parameter is used to decide how many\n"


 27: "sigma^2 into the Gaussian adaptive moment to extend the moment\n"


 28: "calculation, with the weight being defined as 0 beyond this point.\n"


 29: "i.e., if max_moment_nsig2 is set to 25, then the Gaussian is\n"


 30: "extended to (r^2/sigma^2)=25, with proper accounting for elliptical\n"


 31: "geometry.  If this parameter is set to some very large number, then\n"


 32: "the weight is never set to zero and the exponential function is\n"


 33: "always called. Note: GalSim script devel/modules/test_mom_timing.py\n"


 34: "was used to choose a value of 25 as being optimal, in that for the\n"


 35: "cases that were tested, the speedups were typically factors of\n"


 36: "several, but the results of moments and shear estimation were\n"


 37: "changed by <10^-5.  Not all possible cases were checked, and so for\n"


 38: "use of this code for unusual cases, we recommend that users check\n"


 39: "that this value does not affect accuracy, and/or set it to some\n"


 40: "large value to completely disable this optimization.\n"


 41: cdef double MAX_MOMENT_NSIG2 = 25.


  __pyx_v_16adaptive_moments_MAX_MOMENT_NSIG2 = 25.;

 80:     # rho2 = Minv_xx(x-Mx)^2 + 2Minv_xy(x-Mx)(y-My) + Minv_yy(y-My)^2


 81:     # The minimum/maximum y that have a solution rho2 = max_moment_nsig2 is at:


 82:     #   2*Minv_xx*(x-Mx) + 2Minv_xy(y-My) = 0


 83:     # rho2 = Minv_xx (Minv_xy(y-My)/Minv_xx)^2


 84:     #           - 2Minv_xy(Minv_xy(y-My)/Minv_xx)(y-My)


 85:     #           + Minv_yy(y-My)^2

 88:     #      = (1/detM) / Minv_xx (y-My)^2


 89:     #      = (1/Myy) (y-My)^2

/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_16adaptive_moments_5centered_moment(PyObject *__pyx_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_16adaptive_moments_4centered_moment[] = "Calculate centered moments\n\n    Parameters\n    ----------\n    data : array\n        2d image array\n\n    p, q : int\n        The moments we are interested in. p,q for x,y\n\n    Mx, My : floats\n        The centroids of the image.\n\n    Mxx, Mxy, Myy : floats\n        The second moment weight matrix. See the notes below on the extra\n        factor of two compared to the actual centered moment.\n\n    Returns\n    -------\n    mu_pq : float\n        The centered adaptive moment.\n\n    Notes\n    -----\n    Because of the 2 in eq (5) of Hirata et al 2004, the second moment Ms in\n    the input are /twice/ the value of the centered moments I would obtain\n    otherwise. When you measure ellipticities it generally doesn't matter since\n    you normalize by Mxx + Myy, thus cancelling the factor of two. In my\n    analysis, however, I have kept these separate so this is good to\n    understand.\n\n    ie Mxx = 2 <x^2>, Mxy = 2 <xy>, Myy = 2 <y^2>\n    but Mx = <x>, My = <y>\n\n    consequently the T/2 in (4) = e0 = <x^2> + <y^2>\n\n    ";

 296:         np.ndarray[DTYPE_t, ndim=2] data,


 297:         int p, int q,


 298:         double Mx, double My,


 299:         double Mxx, double Mxy, double Myy):


 300: 


 301:     """Calculate centered moments


 302: 


 303:     Parameters


 304:     ----------


 305:     data : array


 306:         2d image array


 307: 


 308:     p, q : int


 309:         The moments we are interested in. p,q for x,y


 310: 


 311:     Mx, My : floats


 312:         The centroids of the image.


 313: 


 314:     Mxx, Mxy, Myy : floats


 315:         The second moment weight matrix. See the notes below on the extra


 316:         factor of two compared to the actual centered moment.


 317: 


 318:     Returns


 319:     -------


 320:     mu_pq : float


 321:         The centered adaptive moment.


 322: 


 323:     Notes


 324:     -----


 325:     Because of the 2 in eq (5) of Hirata et al 2004, the second moment Ms in


 326:     the input are /twice/ the value of the centered moments I would obtain


 327:     otherwise. When you measure ellipticities it generally doesn't matter since


 328:     you normalize by Mxx + Myy, thus cancelling the factor of two. In my


 329:     analysis, however, I have kept these separate so this is good to


 330:     understand.


 331: 


 332:     ie Mxx = 2 <x^2>, Mxy = 2 <xy>, Myy = 2 <y^2>


 333:     but Mx = <x>, My = <y>


 334: 


 335:     consequently the T/2 in (4) = e0 = <x^2> + <y^2>


 336: 


 337:     """


 338: 


 339:     cdef double A = 0


  __pyx_v_A = 0.0;

 340:     cdef double mu_pq = 0


  __pyx_v_mu_pq = 0.0;

 342:     cdef int xmin = 0

  __pyx_v_ymax = (__pyx_v_data->dimensions[0]);

 345:     cdef int xmax = data.shape[1]


  __pyx_v_xmax = (__pyx_v_data->dimensions[1]);

 346: 


 347:     cdef double detM = Mxx * Myy - Mxy * Mxy

  if (__pyx_t_1) {
